newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Enough food for Asia-Pacific, economists say.
newsitem.headline: Enough food for Asia-Pacific, economists say.

text.p: There will be enough food in the Asia-Pacific region for the next 20 years despite the increasing appetite of China and other emerging countries, economists said on Thursday.
Economists attending a three-day conference in Manila on food and agricultural policy challenges in the region said they expected technological advances to bolster food production.

"The region's food basket is expected to produce more at cheaper costs, enough to offset projected rise in consumption from developing countries, primarily due to advances made in biotechnology," said Carl Pray, an economics professor from Rutgers University in New Jersey.
Pray said he expected losses due to pests and diseases in agricultural products to lessen because of genetic engineering.
"Biotechnology is going to pay off in the next 10 to 20 years, and losses due to pests and diseases will go down," Pray said in an interview.
Robert Evenson, professor of economics at Yale University, said on Tuesday he expected grain imports to rise to feed increasingly well-off China and other economies in the region.
Rising grain imports from emerging countries would add pressure on prices in the short term, other economists said.

"Increases in China's food imports will slightly raise world prices for wheat, maize and drive up world prices for livestock products as well as feed grains," Jikun Huang, an economist at the Chinese Academy of Agriculture Sciences, said in a paper presented at the meeting which ended on Thursday.
Pray said he expected China, which recently became a net grain importer, would eventually increase its food supply to feed its swelling population.
"Eventually, China will produce a lot more, and the rest of Asia-Pacific countries," he added.
